Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Integrated studies of early stages of continental extension: From incipient (Okavango) to young (Malawi) rifts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Our current understanding of continental rifting is largely based on studies of evolved and relict rift systems. Observations from these studies have motivated and constrained numerical models that describe rift evolution from initiation to rupture. However, there are very few field observations that constrain processes occurring at the earliest stages of rifting and the structural controls on these processes. This project involves a project to investigate the question of what happens in the early stages of continental rifting. The East African Rift System (EARS), because of its proximity to the pole of rotation, exhibits a strong gradient in rift evolution along its length. This provides a unique opportunity to investigate the processes that drive rift initiation and control early rift localization.

The PIs will undertake a multidisciplinary investigation of the southwest branch of the EARS, which includes the very early stage Okavango Rift Zone, where classic geomorphic rift features are just beginning to emerge, and the Mweru, Luangwa (Zambia) and Malawi Rifts, where geomorphic features are fully developed but magma (if present) has yet to breach the surface. The PIs will apply a combination of geophysical, geological, geochemical and geodynamic techniques across the southwest branch of the EARS to test the predictions of those hypotheses. Passive seismic data will constrain lithospheric-scale structure and upper-mantle flow patterns. Wide angle seismic profiling, along with gravity data, will constrain variations in crustal and uppermost mantle structure. Magnetotelluric measurements will provide system-scale constraints on lithospheric thin spots and the presence of melt, while remote sensing and field mapping will be used to map surface deformation. Geochemical analysis of hot spring fluids will identify the presence of mantle-derived melts. Geodynamic modeling will synthesize the new geophysical observations and geochemical results to develop the next generation of continental rifting models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Continental rifting, i.e., the fracturing and fragmentation of old continents, is a fundamental and poorly understood process in the evolution of the Earth. Rifting leads to elongated valleys, such as those observed in the southwestern United States (the Rio Grande rift), Siberia (the Baikal rift), and East Africa (the East African rift system). Continuing continental rifting could eventually lead to the formation of giant ocean basins, such as the Atlantic Ocean. The close similarity between the western and eastern Atlantic coastlines strongly indicates that the continents now separated by the Atlantic were once together. Continental rifts and continental shelves on the edge of ocean basins (such as the northern Gulf of Mexico) contain about 70% of the world’s hydrocarbon reserve. Therefore, studying continental rifting is not only important for understanding how the Earth works, but can also benefit the society by providing strategic guidance for more efficient exploration of natural resources.

While the volcanic mature segments of the East African Rift System (EARS) have been investigated by numerous geological, geochemical, and geophysical studies, the young and non-volcanic segments, such as those found in Botswana and Malawi, were poorly understood prior to this project. The Missouri University of Science and Technology portion of the project, which is entitled “Collaborative research: Integrated studies of early stages of continental extension: From incipient (Okavango) to young (Malawi) rifts”, has two components: 1) surface geological structural investigations of the Okavango rift zone (ORZ) using on-site field observations and satellite remote sensing data; 2) imaging the crust and mantle structure beneath the ORZ and the Malawi rift zone (MRZ) using seismic data continuously recorded by 50 stations installed along 3 profiles with a total length of 2500 km.

A number of robust seismological and geological techniques have been applied to the outstanding data set. The major conclusion is that the incipient Okavango and young Malawi rifts are not associated with active upwelling of hot mantle materials, which are commonly observed beneath mature sections of the East African Rift System. Instead, the minor thinning of the crust, normal mantle flow field, slight decrease of mantle velocities due to decompression melting of the asthenosphere, as well as the normal thickness of the mantle transition zone (which is the region between about 410 km and 660 km depths) all point to a “passive” model of rifting, i.e., the rifts were initiated by relative movement of ancient continental blocks along pre-existing zones of weakness.

Broader Impacts:

In addition to the principal investigators, three PhD students have been actively involved in all the phases of the field and data analysis work. The students have been sufficiently trained as a result of the project. The broader impacts of the project also extended to the participating African countries. The field teams were accompanied by local scientists, who were able to obtain hands-on experience on the installation and operation of the state-of-the-art instruments. Several of them visited the United States and got trained at the PASSCAL Instrument Center in New Mexico, as well as at Missouri S&T for the operation of the seismological instruments and data processing software. Results from the projects have been used in several undergraduate or graduate level courses including Structural Geology, Introduction to Geophysics, Computational Geophysics, and Advanced Geophysical Data Processing. They were also used for public outreach activities.
